newsitem.title: USA: Study predicts information technology merger race.
newsitem.headline: Study predicts information technology merger race.

text.p: Nearly 75 percent of North American information technology firms are expected to pursue mergers or acquisitions over the next 12 months, according to a forecast released Tuesday by consulting firm Broadview Associates.
The figures reflect an increase from last year's survey, when 64 percent of companies said they expected to participate in the merger boom.
Most of the activity is expected in the media and content services sector, where 89 percent of media companies surveyed said they are likely to pursue a transaction in 1997.

"The pace of activity is accelerating because (information technology) have found (merger and acquisition) transactions to be a cost and time effective tool for implementing their corporate growth strategies," said Charlie Federman, chairman of Broadview.
Other active sectors include software products and services, telecommunications and hardware products.
Broadview said the survey found most activity will involve transactions within, rather than across, technology sectors. Internet-related transaction also will be key to the boom.
The survey found that 67 percent of European information technology firms are likely to pursue transactions in the next 12 months.
The Broadview forecast was based on interviews with 300 senior information technology executives in North America and Europe.
